Subject: STANDARDIZATION OF HELO DECK SAFETY FRAME ARRANGEMENT
Question: Sir       At present  there are various guidelines governing where and how to fit/ install helo deck safety nets. These are primarily governed by Aviation safety requirements. Due to some other issues such as degutting  ease of maintenance etc  the frames/ shoes are at times welded onto the helo deck  sometimes on the ship side and at times with modified arrangements. There have been multiple instances in the past where work up teams recommend to change on a certain ship and the ship has got it done during next AMP/ refit. Threeafter  the aviation inspection/ Ops side indicates it as UNSAT and recommends changes. Each ship of same class at times has different arrangement due to lack of clarity and it is a perennial issue. Re-work also has effect on helo deck paint touch up and and its guarantee. Thus  there is a need to standardize the fitment of helo deck frames once and for all catering to all aviation  safety and functional requirement. It is  strongly recommended that a class of ship-wise standard arrangement be promulgated as a policy directive to put an end to constant changes. The policy may cater suitably to type of aircraft handling of a certain deck  oblique/ astern approach of helo  etc. A suitable change management plan for the same is also recommended.
Comment: Prima facie, this issue pertains to conflicting requirements of seamanship and aviation in the context of placement of Helo Deck Safety Nets (HDSN).   INBR 1760 mandates that in lowered position, the height of the safety nets should be lesser than 50mm in MTRLA and 150mm at deck edge (whichever is applicable, based on rotor-wing craft and deck landing area). HQFOST mandates the nets to have 10 deg upward slope to ensure rollback of personnel on deck. Thus, geometrically speaking, to align with aviation side, HDSN are to affixed on the ship sides.  The seamanship side /DSR highlighted the concerns of ship staff that HDSN at ship sides tend to cause damage to fittings when ships come alongside.  This case has been extensively deliberated at IHQ between WDB, DSR and DNAS. The following emerged:-  (a) For new construction ships -  HDSN at ship side at all locations.  (b) For in-service ships – wherever MRLTA and oblique approach posits problems, HDSN is to be fitted at ship-side. Additionally, 03 in number protector pieces covered with sacrificially damaging polymeric rubber piece (at 07 deg cant from the vertical) are to be provisioned along the length of the helo deck on Port and Starboard side to obviate damage while berthing alongside.

Subject: LIFECYLE APPROACH TOWARDS MAINTENANCE OF ENGINEERING MACHINERY
Question: Dear Sir(s) and collegues    It is a matter of fact that any procurement  maintenance and repair in the navy is considered primarly based on financial implications. To name a few  we find DLs and RAs being deleted from refit/ AMP packages  spares excluded from recommended OEM list in OBS and B&D  parts being cannabilised from operational machinery of ships in refit for rectifying onging defects on operational ships etc. All these actions are either towards bringing down the cost or to decrease the down-time of equipment. The three major organisations involved in the entire lifecylce of a engieering equipment is IHQ MoD(N)  Material Organisation and Naval Dockyards. Synergy between a ship right from its comissioning to the operational phase and during de-commisioning with these three organisation is highly required for a fruitful management of engineering machinery. Sometimes  the lack of planning  foresight and unprecedented defects creates situation which have drastic effects on either the machinery itself or on the money spent on its management. It is time that we think about managing our engineering machinery onboard with an approach which includes assets procurement  operation  maintenance and disposal.     In generi context  asset management (AM) is a further evolution in the maintenence regime and is defined as a much better and more business focused maintenance (Woodstock 2006). AM combines risk-controlled  optimised and life-cycle management of an assest. To break it down into Engineering machinery aspect  the following is part of assest management:-    1. Standardisation of equipments especially auxiliaries and diesel engines    2. Procurements of these equipment in as large numbers as we can wherein equipment are supplied as per current requirement  others are stored and warehoused by the firm    3. Fitment and setting up of these equipments are done by the firm    4. Trainng on operation and ship staff maintenance is delivered during setting up and on regular intervals as per OCRC cycle of the ship    5. Breakdown maintenace is carried out as part of Rate Contract    6. Major overhauls and replacement during mid-life upgradation is carried out as per OCRC of the ship    7. Disposal/ Survey of parts and BER equipment is directly carried out by the firm    8. Regular checks as part of CBPM may also be part of maintenece by the firm    A comprehensive contract which considers all points mentioned above may be taken up during initial procurement of machinery. Financial implications for new machinery can be compared with similar machinery in service by calculateing costs involved during procurement from OEM  setting up cost by comissioning yards  maintenance costs during lifespan of the equipment or ship from ship and yard  and finally cost of spares  stowage  warehousing  transportation and disposal from MO.    Another important aspect is the role of WOT/ trial agencies in accepting these equipment during setting up or repair. All trail agencies should have personnel who are certified to carryout acceptance or quality assesment like an inspector in a civial yard or in the merchant navy holds.       Such an approach towards maintenance will not only decrease the down-time of equipment but also de-stress the chain involved in life-cycle mamangement of the machinery.

Question: The detection  classification and identification of maritime targets in a time bound manner plays a crucial role for initiating timely response and utilising available resources.  Conventional surveillance methods are cost intensive and time consuming  coupling AI/ML with remote sensing can produce state of art detection and identification system which can provide in-depth  real-time and credible information from surveillance data.         Sir  I have designed a prototype application which takes optical aerial image as input and gives Type & class of ship  country of origin and fitted armament. Technical paper on the same I have published in Rozi Light magazine and presented at AI workshop -2022 at INS Valsura.    Need suggestions from domain experts  how I can take this project ahead.         Regards    Lt Amit Kasana    ALO  INS Shakti
Comment: Dear Amit    A really novel use case of Machine Learning that you have been able to conceptualise and develop. Kudos!    While I have not had the oppurtinity to read your article in JEEE/ Rozi Light  based on limited reading I have on subject till day  I would suggest that you may check up on following aspects before the model to be 'deployable' grade.    1. ML models are never static and are continiously evolving  so there is a requirement to keep the model to be fed with sufficient new data to ensure that it remains relevant. Necessary mechanisms have to be factored.    2. Model Selection and selection of performance metrics are the core essentials  so an interaction with users (domain experts) wrt selection of metrics is required before a model is considered to be a viable candidate.    3. Care has to be taken that the model is not overfitting (too acurate) or under-fitting. A very common problem. Zero Error Syndrome here is a definite no-no.    4. Undertake data augmentation and ensure that data does not have a class skew.    5. Try evaluating the data against various pre-trained models and see which model works the best for your case.    6. Since computing resources are going to me limited at the edge system (user end)  model also needs to be computationally light.    7. Along with image data check whether you can incorporate ESM data as additional parameters for the classification to be more robust.    8.  Implement MLOPS loop to ensure model reliability and sustainaility.         This is the only few things that come to my mind.    It would be great if you can share your technical paper with me on email (51754Y).     Best of Luck  Keep it Coming and Keep us Posted.

Subject: Alternate Marine Fuel
Question: Is there any research on alternate marine fuel for surface ships being undertaken by the Indian Navy? If yes, may I please know which fuel are we looking into and where is the research being carried out?
Comment: Background. INECR promulgates usage of B-20 blend biodiesel for Shore Generators and MT vehicles as a short-term goal and on small, medium and capital ships as medium-term goal.   2. IN Biodiesel Programme.   As part of the IN Biodiesel Programme, it is intended to commence regular use of biodiesel in a phased manner, commencing with MT vehicles and FICs. Accordingly, a dialogue was initiated with DIBER for provisioning of biodiesel for Naval use in 2016. However, DIBER in consultation with DRDO HQs, intimated that while the requirement of biodiesel for limited trials/ demonstration can be met by them, regular/ continued supply for use on FICs, as part of IN Biodiesel Programme, may not be possible.   3.  Trials Conducted. As part of the IN Biodiesel Programme, trials of indigenously developed biodiesel (produced from Jatropha Curacas) synthesized by DIBER-DRDO, were undertaken in four stages on MT vehicles, shore-based Diesel Generator, DA on a Ferry Craft and DE/ DA on a FIC in 2014-2016. Upon successful trials, demonstration of use of indigenous biodiesel on a FIC during Presidential Review was undertaken during IFR-2016. Details of biodiesel trials undertaken is enumerated below:-   (a) SNC : MT vehicles at INS Shivaji (Nov - Dec 14).  (b) WNC : DG set of fuel barge -7 (Oct 15).  (c) ENC : Shore Generator at Naval Dockyard (Oct 15).             FIC T-311 (Jan 16).             FIC 211 (Mar 21).  4. Deliberations with IOCL. Towards transition to biofuel in a sequential manner, IOCL has been continuously engaged over the past few years to provide sustained supply of biodiesel for MT vehicles, however, unavailability of sustained supply of biodiesel has been an area of concern. In Feb 19, the firm agreed to supply B5 blended HSD and subsequent case was taken up for amendment in existing Rate Contract. Amendment to RC was completed in Dec 19. In the last year, M/s IOCL has supplied 192 KL of B-7 blended Biodiesel for MT Vehicles at Vishakhapatnam, however, for sustained supply of biodiesel for use onboard IN ships, M/s IOCL has indicated non-availability on repeated tenders floated by the firm.  5.  Way ahead.       Towards transition to biofuel in a sequential manner from MT vehicles in Phase I; shore generators, FICs & auxiliary in Phase II and Capital Ships in Phase III. IOCL has been continuously engaged over the past few years to commence supply of biodiesel for MT vehicles, however, unavailability of sustained supply of biodiesel has been an area of concern. Although constant endeavors have been made by both IN-IOCL teams, the supply of biodiesel has not yet fructified for IN units. Interaction with the firm’s representatives over the past few months indicate that the firm is in process of setting up the biodiesel plants/ refineries in the country and one such facility has been completed in Panipat. Further, plan of action to counter hurdles towards biodiesel induction is being formulated in consultation with IOCL in the form of an approach paper and roadmap.  This may be treated as official repsonse of DME.

During the visit, the shipyard staff demonstrated a novel method of docking/ undocking vessels viz. 'Balloon Docking'. Videos of docking/ undocking operations undertaken using heavy duty air balloons (pneumatic fenders) were shown to the team. In addition, an actual docking operation of one auxiliary vessel was also demonstrated.     2. The novel 'Balloon Docking' is worth studying in more detail, as we try to make our maintenance processes 'Future Ready',  in view of the following advantages : -     (a) Convenience and flexibility of operations including version change (easy shifting from dock blocks to balloons and vice versa, by inflation/ deflation).     (b) Suitability of docking vessels of all dimensions and tonnage, depending on availability of waterfront area at different shipyards/ dockyards.     (c) Low operating/ capital costs.     (d) Huge potential for indigenisation of the Balloons (Pneumatic Fenders), presently being imported from China.     3. Detailed examination with related costing aspects may pave a roadmap for implementation of this novel method for docking of IN ships and submarines.
Comment: Dear Sir,  1. The concept of 'Balloon Docking' is innovative and could augment the dry dock capability of Yards with considerably low investment. However, the following aspects merit consideration wrt use of ‘balloon docking’ for IN ships: -  (a) This method would be less conducive for docking of ships with underwater appendages below keel (such as sonar dome, propeller, skeg, etc) as is the case with most naval ships, due to risk of damage to the appendage.  (b) The balloons would provide minimal side support, which is provided by shape side blocks or shores in case of normal dry docking. Hence, the method would be more suitable for flat bottom ships such as carrier, tankers, LSTs and certain yard crafts.  (c) Post docking, clearance below keel would be limited, to undertake any major underwater repairs.   2. Notwithstanding the above, 'Balloon Docking' could be used for emergency/ ops docking, when suitable dock slots are not available and limited underwater repair work is planned, subject to availability of favourably sloping waterfront area at the yard premises.  Regards,  Cdr Vipin PG

Videos of docking/ undocking operations undertaken using heavy duty air balloons (pneumatic fenders) were shown to the team. In addition, an actual docking operation of one auxiliary vessel was also demonstrated.     2. The novel 'Balloon Docking' is worth studying in more detail, as we try to make our maintenance processes 'Future Ready',  in view of the following advantages : -     (a) Convenience and flexibility of operations including version change (easy shifting from dock blocks to balloons and vice versa, by inflation/ deflation).     (b) Suitability of docking vessels of all dimensions and tonnage, depending on availability of waterfront area at different shipyards/ dockyards.     (c) Low operating/ capital costs.     (d) Huge potential for indigenisation of the Balloons (Pneumatic Fenders), presently being imported from China.     3. It is proposed that the ‘Balloon Docking’ methodology be examined by all IN Repair Yards as part of the study on ‘Transformation of Repair Yards’. Detailed examination with related costing aspects may pave a roadmap for implementation of this novel method for docking of IN ships and submarines.

Subject: Maintenance of bilges onboard ships
Question: Usage of corrosion inhibitor tablets designed NMRL for ensuring bilge hygiene and preventing corrosion due to water accumulation of bilges  - effectiveness of the same needs to be ascertained in realtime. Has it been done before and what were the results? Though, it  has been promulgated by IHQ as good practices but supply has not commenced onboard for trial purposes.
Comment: The author of the post has sought information on effectiveness of the pellets in real time and commencement of supply onboard. With regards to effectiveness of pellets, trial application of corrosion inhibiting pellets was undertaken with steel coupons immersed in bilge water having inhibitor pellets dispersed, onboard Kolkata & Beas. The pellets comprise of Gluconate & Molybdate salts of zinc, sodium and calcium for corrosion inhibition of HSLA steel in bilge waters. It was observed during the trials that the pellets formed a protective inhibitor layer by adsorbing the inhibitor component on the metal surface thereby reducing the contact of the metal from bilge water. Based on gravimetric (weight loss) analysis, a corrosion inhibition efficiency of 90% was achieved during the trials. With regards to commencement of supply onboard, IHQ/DNA vide letter NC/0528 dated 28 Feb 23 had requested Command HQs to forward ship wise details to respective MOs by Mar 23 towards inclusion of corrosion inhibiting pellets as ARS for supply onboard IN ships. Accordingly, Command HQs have forwarded the ship wise details to MOs in Mar 23 and procurement action at MOs is in progress. Additionally, in order to meet the interim requirement of Corrosion Inhibitor Pellets, on request of IHQ/ DNA, NMRL has manufactured 400 kgs of pellets which have been distributed to respective Command Headquarters (100 kgs each). The supply of these pellets is in progress and has been completed on various class of ships viz Vikramaditya, Aditya & Deepak, B class, Teg class, Talwar class, P15B, P17A, Makar, FAC, WJFAC etc. Further, onsite training has been undertaken by NMRL for SS at respective command HQs towards effective/ proper usage of the pellets.

Subject: YARD SERVICE MEDAL FOR PERSONNEL OF TECHNICAL BRANCHES
Question: YARD SERVICE MEDAL FOR PERSONNEL OF TECHNICAL BRANCHES     Background.           Presently, Sea service medal and Long Sea service medal are awarded to Naval personnel iaw The Gazette of India, June 24,2017 with following criteria: -     (a)          Sea Service Medal is awarded to Personnel who have completed 2190 days (06 years) of cumulative afloat service undertaking operations at sea as safety of Sea Lines of communication, anti-piracy and costal security missions.     (b)          Long Sea Service Medal is awarded to Personnel who have completed 3285 days (09 years) of cumulative afloat service undertaking operations at sea as safety of Sea Lines of communication, anti-piracy and costal security missions.     Further, a proposal for twelve-year sea service is also being introduced and may lead to disparity between the branches of IN as technical Officers are highly unlikely to be posted for such long durations on sea billets.     Sea Service of Personnel of Technical Branch.        The cumulative sea service of personnel from Technical branches viz. Engineering, Electrical and Naval Constructor is lesser as compared to their counterparts of Executive branch due to service requirements and area of responsibility being largely maintenance oriented. Due to this the personnel from technical branches for a large tenure of their service are employed in maintenance agencies viz. Naval Dockyard, Naval Ship Repair Yards, Fleet Maintenance Units, and Flotilla Technical Support Units.     Role of Personnel of Maintenance Agencies.            The primary role of all Maintenance agencies is to assist the operational platforms in remaining sea worthy by undertaking timely maintenance routines and undertaking DI/ DR. The repair and maintenance of ships is a complex task that requires specialized skills and expertise. Every class of ship differs in terms of the type of equipment fitted onboard. Personnel posted in Repair agencies have to gain expertise in equipment of all class of ships towards ensuring that maintenance work is done in the most efficient and correct manner. The personnel should not only have the detailed knowledge of ships system but also the ability to work in challenging conditions, including extreme heat and confined spaces and often hazardous environment. Additionally, the job of the personnel is very dynamic in nature. For example, Officers posted in Repair yards also initiate financial cases for repair work despite having no vertical specialization in the same.     Yard Service Medal           It is understood that, towards recognizing the contributions of sailors who have provided essential support services to naval operations, such as maintenance and repair of ships, a medal called Navy Yard and Marine Depot Service Medal is awarded by the US Navy. This Medal is awarded to naval personnel who have served a minimum of two years of continuous duty at a Navy Yard, or other qualifying repair agencies. A medal on similar lines towards appreciating the efforts of IN personnel posted at repair yards for maintaining operational availability of platforms may be introduced with the following eligibility criteria: -     (a)          Units  Naval Dockyards, Naval Ship Repair Yards, Fleet Maintenance Unit,  Flotilla Technical Support Unit.     (b)          Service          03 years service at yard.
